author: By Sara Aridi
title: Attend a Black-Tie Gala From Your Living Room
description: Many fancy fundraisers have moved online and are offering low-price or free tickets for virtual attendees.
content: It’s gala season, when nonprofit organizations host their biggest fund-raising events of the year. Many of those events have been canceled or postponed because of the pandemic, but others have moved online and are open to those who don’t have $1,000 or more for a table (donations are strongly encouraged).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: In Miami-Dade County, Younger Cuban Voters Offer Opening for Trump
description: Newer Cuban immigrants who previously had little engagement in American politics have started to identify as Trump Republicans. It could give the president a boost in a critical swing state.
content: MIAMI — The conventional wisdom about the Florida electorate has long been that Miami-Dade County’s unavoidable political destiny was to turn even more Democratic as younger Cuban-Americans replaced the older Cuban exiles who formed a powerful Republican stronghold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Infection of Pence Aides Raises New Questions About Trump’s Virus Response
description: From the beginning, the president has turned mask wearing and other preventive measures into a loyalty test. He and his aides have taken the same approach inside the White House.
content: Follow our live coverage of the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Game Day in Green Bay: Empty Sports Bars, Full Hospitals
description: Uncontrolled spread of the coronavirus in northeastern Wisconsin has done what little else could: subdue a city’s urge to cheer on its beloved Packers together.
content: GREEN BAY, Wis. — In a town that lives or dies with its Packers, the metaphor takes on a somewhat chilling hue in the middle of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The Ballet Photo-Sharing Scandal Enters a New Phase in Court
description: The former New York City Ballet dancer who sent intimate photos of his girlfriend to others presents himself as a victim in a new court filing.
content: A woman’s lawsuit that once challenged the culture of the New York City Ballet withered last month when a judge dismissed the company and several other defendants from the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Grow a Hydroponic Garden
description: It’s getting cold out there. Take your pandemic gardening inside.
content: Emily Marsh, who lives in Sonoma County, Calif., always thought the best thing about gardening was the feel of soil on her fingertips. But last year she and her fiancé moved to a townhouse with an 8-by-12-foot concrete slab for a backyard. As lockdowns in California stretched into the month of May, and Ms. Marsh, 30 and a co-owner of a janitorial company, read about the surge in gardens, she felt the urge to plant her own. But her only real option was a hydroponic setup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Members of Pence’s Inner Circle Test Positive for Coronavirus
description: Along with Marc Short, the vice president’s chief of staff, three additional staff members and a Pence adviser have also tested positive, according to people briefed on the developments.
content: Follow our live coverage of the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Pence’s chief of staff and several other aides test positive for the virus.
description: At least three top aides to Vice President Mike Pence have tested positive for the coronavirus in the last few days, people briefed on the matter said. The test results raise fresh questions about the safety protocols at the White House, where masks are not routinely worn.
content: At least three top aides to Vice President Mike Pence have tested positive for the coronavirus in the last few days, people briefed on the matter said. The test results raise fresh questions about the safety protocols at the White House, where masks are not routinely worn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Ana Swanson and Glenn Thrush
title: Kodak Loan Debacle Puts a New Agency in the Hot Seat
description: A stumbling effort to prop up the domestic generic drugs sector underscores the challenges of a Trump administration industrial policy.
content: WASHINGTON — At a virtual conference in September, Adam Boehler, chief executive of the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation, described his nascent agency as a bulwark against China’s “economic colonialism” — with $60 billion in annual lending authority to counter Beijing’s strategy of spreading its global influence with low-interest infrastructure loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Tropical Storm Zeta Strengthens as It Approaches Gulf Coast
description: Zeta is expected to become a hurricane before it makes landfall in the United States on Wednesday. It is the 27th named storm of an unusually active Atlantic hurricane season.
content: Tropical Storm Zeta formed in the Caribbean over the weekend and could be at or near hurricane strength by the time it makes landfall on the Gulf Coast on Wednesday, the National Hurricane Center said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: In coronavirus testing, false positives are more hazardous than they might seem.
description: In the high-stakes world of coronavirus testing, false positives are widely considered to be benign in comparison with false negatives, which can deprive infected people of treatment and embolden them to mingle with others, hastening the spread of disease.
content: In the high-stakes world of coronavirus testing, false positives are widely considered to be benign in comparison with false negatives, which can deprive infected people of treatment and embolden them to mingle with others, hastening the spread of disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘School for Wives’ Review: The Enchantment Is Visual
description: Grooming a naïve maiden to be an obedient bride is bound to fail, or at least be sorely tested, when Molière spins the love story.
content: Sometimes you get a ward and isolate her for years, grooming her to be your naïve bride against her will, and in the end, all you have to show for it are canceled nuptials and a whole lot of headaches. Don’t you just hate when that happens?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A Headache for Big Tech
description: The government filed an antitrust lawsuit against Google and is considering one against Facebook, too.
content: Welcome to the weirdest (and legitimately scariest) Halloween week ever. Surprisingly, candy sales are up this year — perhaps it’s the stress eating? Here’s what you need to know in business and tech news going into Monday. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Rays Stun the Dodgers With a Chaotic Walk-Off Win in Game 4
description: The Dodgers needed one more out to take a 3-1 lead in the Series, but they made two mistakes on a wild final play that gave the Rays a memorable Game 4 victory.
content: You could watch the final play of the Tampa Bay Rays’ 8-7 win over the Los Angeles Dodgers in Game 4 of the World Series dozens of times and probably still struggle to comprehend exactly what occurred. You wouldn’t be alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellora Derenoncourt and Claire Montialoux
title: To Reduce Racial Inequality, Raise the Minimum Wage
description: Diversity and inclusion programs for elites are tokens. A large wage increase that would most benefit the Black working class is far better.
content: After a summer of protests over the killing of George Floyd broadened into a wider reckoning on racial injustice, corporate America and the political establishment unleashed a flurry of promises to combat systemic racism. Diversity initiatives have been launched; high-profile companies in several sectors have settled on the advancement of a few people of color in their hierarchies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘JQA’ Review: Fictional History That Resonates Today
description: In Aaron Posner’s play, there is more than one John Quincy Adams, but only one way to ensure that American democracy endures.
content: Sounding like a 19th-century MSNBC pundit, John Quincy Adams once complained to his mother, Abigail, that America was interested “in personality rather than actual plans or programs.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Wednesdays Are the Days He Drives Into Manhattan From Brooklyn’
description: Flirting on Mott Street, waiting for the M and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Punishes Titans for Their Handling of Coronavirus Outbreak
description: A heavy fine, but no suspensions, came after two dozen players and staff members tested positive for the virus.
content: The N.F.L. has fined the Tennessee Titans $350,000 for their handling of the largest outbreak of coronavirus infections this season, which forced the league to reschedule an array of games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: China tackles an outbreak in Kashgar.
content: The authorities in China have ordered widespread testing and travel restrictions for the city of Kashgar in the country’s far west after a single asymptomatic case of coronavirus was detected on Saturday. By Sunday afternoon, 137 asymptomatic cases had been discovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Tristan Spinski
title: New Spirits Rise in Old, Repurposed Churches
description: For years, attendance rates have dropped and congregations have closed nationwide. But many reused religious spaces are still sanctuaries.
content: The pandemic has thrown religious worship into turmoil. Some congregations spent months meeting over Zoom, uncertain if in-person worship could be safe. Others struggled to keep the doors open as contributions declined. A few have closed their doors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump, in Wisconsin, says the virus is ‘rounding the turn’ while cases climb.
description: For his third rally on Saturday, President Trump arrived in Waukesha, Wis., saying he felt better after he was hospitalized for Covid-19 than he did before. His only acknowledgment of the spiking rates of the virus in Wisconsin, where there were 4,660 new cases and 28 deaths on Saturday, was to claim that the United States included in its death counts people suffering from other ailments, like heart conditions.
content: For his third rally on Saturday, President Trump arrived in Waukesha, Wis., saying he felt better after he was hospitalized for Covid-19 than he did before. His only acknowledgment of the spiking rates of the virus in Wisconsin, where there were 4,660 new cases and 28 deaths on Saturday, was to claim that the United States included in its death counts people suffering from other ailments, like heart conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Election May Hinge on Pennsylvania. Can the Polls Get the State Right?
description: Polling averages show Joseph R. Biden Jr. with a lead in Pennsylvania, but surveys can’t account for possibilities like voter suppression.
content: [Follow our live polls tracker on Trump vs Biden.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: How to Talk to Friends and Family Who Share Conspiracy Theories
description: Fringe movements will persist long after Election Day. Here’s how to help.
content: Increasingly, friends, colleagues and readers share the same story with me: Online, somebody they know and love has stumbled into the treacherous world of online conspiracy theories and, in some cases, might not even know it. I’m often asked: How do you talk to people you care about who might be on the precipice of or headed down the conspiratorial rabbit hole?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Spoofs the Final Debate and Adele Sings (a Little)
description: Alec Baldwin and Jim Carrey returned to their roles as Donald Trump and Joe Biden in a “Saturday Night Live” parody of Thursday’s face-off between the two candidates.
content: Adele hosted “Saturday Night Live” this weekend, and to answer your most pressing question: Yes, she did sing, briefly, though H.E.R. was officially the musical guest. But first, there was a parody of Thursday’s second and final presidential debate to get through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: 20-Year-Old Tourist Killed by Stray Bullet in Brooklyn
description: Ethan Williams, who had long dreamed of moving to New York, became another victim of the wave of gun violence that has shaken the city.
content: Ethan Williams arrived in New York last week to pursue his dreams of becoming a professional skateboarder, a goal that he had long envisioned would bring him to the city. But days later, he became another victim of a wave of deadly gun violence that has shaken the city when a stray bullet struck him in the chest outside his Airbnb apartment in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Border Patrol Agents Fatally Shoot Driver in Texas
description: The driver was shot in Laredo on Friday after he reversed his car into an agent and refused orders to stop, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection.
content: Border Patrol agents shot and killed the driver of a car that had been carrying unauthorized immigrants in Laredo, Texas, on Friday, after the car reversed into an agent and pinned him against another vehicle, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner, Matthew Futterman and Marc Stein
title: After making a comeback during the pandemic, pro sports face a tough second act.
description: In mid-March, as the pandemic forced extensive lockdowns throughout the United States, professional sports came to a halt, with the very real possibility that no champions would be crowned in basketball, hockey or baseball.
content: In mid-March, as the pandemic forced extensive lockdowns throughout the United States, professional sports came to a halt, with the very real possibility that no champions would be crowned in basketball, hockey or baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Pledges Ambitious Climate Action. Here’s What He Could Actually Do.
description: If elected, Joe Biden and his allies are preparing to pass climate change legislation, piece by piece — knowing full well that the candidate’s $2 trillion plan would be a tough sell.
content: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s $2 trillion plan to fight global warming is the most ambitious climate policy proposed by a leading presidential candidate, a political lightning rod spotlighted on Thursday night when the Democratic nominee acknowledged during a debate that it would “transition” the country “from the oil industry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: In hot spots around the country, hospitals are reaching their limits.
description: With the coronavirus spreading out of control in many parts of the United States and daily case counts once again setting records, health experts have warned that it is only a matter of time before the pressure on hospitals mounts to the breaking point.
content: With the coronavirus spreading out of control in many parts of the United States and daily case counts once again setting records, health experts have warned that it is only a matter of time before the pressure on hospitals mounts to the breaking point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Marc Stein
title: Sports Came Back in 2020. Now Comes the Hard Part.
description: Aggressive coronavirus testing made the restart of professional sports possible, but the financial pain of empty arenas lingers and plans for next year are up in the air.
content: Professional sports figured out how to sputter back to life over the past three months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Murder Hornet
description: Eric Bornstein’s second entry is sure to generate some buzz.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — You’ve gotta love a puzzle with a clue like “murder hornet” (1D), right? That started me out with a smile, even though any threat to our planet’s bees is certainly a dire concern, and I certainly wouldn’t want any of you to end up near the business end of one of those killers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Recall those days when we used to gather indoors and listen to live music, and make Café Carlyle’s lobster bisque, or its chicken hash.
content: Good morning. It’s the cabaret queen Barbara Cook’s birthday, and she would have been 92. It got me thinking about all the good preshow meals I knocked down at Café Carlyle before seeing her sing or seeing the Pizzarellis play. I wrote about that once, a long time ago, and emerged with a couple of great recipes to consider making on a Sunday in fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Crooks and Samir Deger-Sen
title: We Were Clerks at the Supreme Court. Its Legitimacy Is Now in Question.
description: Brazen politics in Amy Coney Barrett’s confirmation process threatens the court’s standing with the public.
content: We are lawyers who clerked for Justice Anthony Kennedy, a lifelong conservative appointed to the Supreme Court by President Ronald Reagan. We urge the Senate not to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett or any nominee until after the presidential election. Rushing through a confirmation with an election underway threatens the very legitimacy of the court.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Improbably, Sports Made It Back in 2020. Now, the Hard Part
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 25, 2020.
content: “The reality is all planning for 2021 for us, and for every other business in America, has to have an asterisk next to it in terms of what the course of the virus is going to be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: The Rise of Wilton Gregory, the First African-American Cardinal
description: Archbishop Gregory led the U.S. Roman Catholic Church’s response to its sexual abuse crisis and more recently has pushed for better race relations in the church. Here is what we know about him.
content: Wilton Gregory, the archbishop of Washington, D.C., and a leader of the U.S. Roman Catholic Church’s response to its sexual abuse crisis, was among 13 new cardinals Pope Francis installed on Nov. 28, becoming the first African-American cardinal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: A Voting Rights Battle in a School Board ‘Coup’
description: For Black residents of Sumter County, the fight for representation echoed the civil rights era. For white residents, it reflected the anxiety, made manifest by the Trump era, of maintaining power over institutions even without the votes to do so.
content: AMERICUS, Ga. — One mother worked at Habitat for Humanity. The other helped teenagers who had run afoul of the law. Their sons played soccer together, and for a few years, the two women also sat on the county school board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pascale Bonnefoy
title: ‘An End to the Chapter of Dictatorship’: Chileans Vote to Draft a New Constitution
description: Voters overwhelmingly approved a bid to scrap the charter inherited from Gen. Augusto Pinochet’s dictatorship, a move that could set a new course for the country.
content: SANTIAGO, Chile — The protests started over a small hike in metro fares, then exploded into a broad reckoning over inequality that shook Chile for weeks. Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators poured into the streets, calling for sweeping change in their society, with higher wages and pensions, better health care and education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘Dear Evan Hansen’ and ‘Leopoldstadt’ Pick Up Olivier Awards
description: Sam Tutty, Sharon D. Clarke and Andrew Scott are among the actors to triumph at the coronavirus-delayed awards, the British equivalent of the Tonys.
content: LONDON — “Dear Evan Hansen,” the hit musical about an anxious teenager who takes advantage of a fateful encounter with a schoolmate, was one of the big winners at the Olivier Awards on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Clifford
title: Schools Clamored for Seesaw’s App. That Was Good News, and Bad News.
description: It wasn’t simple to become a do-it-all education tool almost overnight.
content: The first requests that upended Seesaw, a popular classroom app, came in January from teachers and education officials abroad. Their schools were shutting down because of the coronavirus, and they urgently wanted the app adjusted for remote learning. The company figured it could do that with a single short hackathon project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 7 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Arizona shocked Seattle in overtime, Baker Mayfield caught fire after a rough start and the Steelers held on to beat the Titans.
content: Several games came down to the final play in a day of surprising results, but it all felt like an appetizer for the main course once Seattle and Arizona squared off in an absolute classic in prime time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan Hale
title: 2 New Books Answer Kids’ Pre-Election Questions
description: A review in comics format helps inquisitive young citizens learn how we choose who runs our country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Lee Kun-hee, Who Built Samsung Into a Global Giant, Dies at 78
description: Mr. Lee was convicted — and pardoned — twice for white-collar crimes, in a sign of the ills in South Korea’s relationship with its business dynasties.
content: Lee Kun-hee, who built Samsung into a global giant of smartphones, televisions and computer chips but was twice convicted — and, in a pattern that has become typical in South Korea, twice pardoned — for white-collar crimes committed along the way, died on Sunday in Seoul, the South Korean capital. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Dunkin’ Brands Is in Talks to Sell Itself and Go Private
description: The parent of Dunkin’ and Baskin Robbins is negotiating with a private-equity-backed company for a takeover that values the coffee company at nearly $9 billion.
content: Dunkin’ Brands, the parent company of the Dunkin’ and Baskin Robbins chains, is in talks to sell itself to a private equity-backed company, Inspire Brands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats Hope 2020 Is the Year They Flip the Texas House
description: Republicans have controlled the state government since 2003. An anti-Trump surge could give Democrats a crucial boost.
content: BEDFORD, Texas — Deep in the suburbs northeast of Fort Worth, Democrats trying to win the Texas House for the first time in years have been getting help from a surprising source.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Over Democratic Fury, Republicans Push Barrett to Brink of Confirmation
description: A near party-line vote on Sunday to cut off debate over Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s Supreme Court nomination set up a final confirmation vote on Monday.
content: WASHINGTON — A divisive drive to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court before Election Day wound on Sunday toward its expected end, as Senate Republicans overcame Democratic protests to limit debate and set up a final confirmation vote for Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 25, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 25, 2020.
content: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Samantha McCluskey and Louis Keleher misstated the year of the couple’s first date. It was in 2016, not 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: Jack Reacher Works Alone. That Doesn’t Mean His Author Has To.
description: With “The Sentinel,” the action-packed new Reacher novel, Lee Child collaborates with his younger brother, Andrew Child, who will take over the series from here.
content: A man breaks into a bar. He’s looking to threaten its owner for not paying a band. He is Jack Reacher, the star of — wait a minute, since when does Jack Reacher do break-ins and shakedowns? Since now, when the Reacher series goes through a bumpy passage as Lee Child, who began the series in 1997, turns it over to his much younger brother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: These Sisters Have Transformed the Piano Duo
description: Katia and Marielle Labèque have been playing, and enlarging, the two-piano repertory for over 50 years.
content: AHETZE, France — “Oh, look!” said the pianist Katia Labèque, pushing aside some neatly ironed clothes hanging on a rack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: With a little more than a week until Election Day, Trump and Biden make closing pitches on ‘60 Minutes.’
description: Even before the “60 Minutes” interviews with the candidates aired, they attracted attention, in Mr. Biden’s case because of comments on the Supreme Court, and in Mr. Trump’s case because he walked out.
content: Nine days before Election Day, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. offered sharply divergent visions for the country — including the coronavirus pandemic, the economy and foreign policy — in wide-ranging interviews on “60 Minutes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Treaty to Prohibit Nuclear Weapons Passes Important Threshold
description: Fifty countries have now ratified the treaty, so it will become international law. The United States and the eight other nuclear-armed powers reject it but have failed to stop its advance.
content: A treaty aimed at destroying all nuclear weapons and forever prohibiting their use has hit an important benchmark, with Honduras becoming the 50th country to ratify the accord — the minimum needed for it to enter into force as international law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: 2020 Election, Coronavirus Surge, Fall Cocktails: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Times Square Billboards With Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner Stir Skirmish
description: The couple’s lawyer threatens to sue over scathing billboards that were put up by an anti-Trump group, the Lincoln Project.
content: In July, Ivanka Trump released a photo of herself cradling a can of Goya beans in an effort to support a Trump-friendly company facing a boycott.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: N.Y.C. billboards pair Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner with damning quotes and statistics.
description: On Thursday morning, the Lincoln Project, an anti-Trump group made up mostly of Republicans, put up two billboards in Times Square. On one, Ivanka Trump, the president’s daughter and a senior White House adviser, gestures to statistics about Covid-19 deaths.
content: On Thursday morning, the Lincoln Project, an anti-Trump group made up mostly of Republicans, put up two billboards in Times Square. On one, Ivanka Trump, the president’s daughter and a senior White House adviser, gestures to statistics about Covid-19 deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Why Trump Can’t Take Red Counties in North Carolina for Granted
description: Even some people in Gastonia, N.C., are a little perplexed about why the president was holding a rally in a small community that’s already in his camp.
content: GASTONIA, N.C. — Republicans in Gaston County still have pictures from the last time a presidential candidate visited here during a general election: They are sun-stained images from 1992, when President George H.W. Bush’s Spirit of America train tour made a stop in the town of Ranlo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: How Matthew Warchus Generated ‘Heat’ in an Empty Theater
description: London’s Old Vic has sold 30,000 tickets to three livestreamed shows, with more to come. “There’s a huge appetite out there,” said Warchus, the artistic director.
content: Early in the pandemic, Matthew Warchus, the artistic director of London’s Old Vic theater, got a lot of attention in the British press for his dire warning about the existential threat to nonprofit theater posed by an indefinite shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Kenneth P. Vogel and Maggie Haberman
title: Questions and Answers About the Bidens and a Deal in China
description: There is no evidence that the former vice president was involved in or profited from a joint venture pursued by his son and brother.
content: In the closing days of the campaign, President Trump and his allies are engaged in a last-ditch effort to raise questions about the ethics of former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. by trying to link Mr. Biden to the international business dealings of Mr. Biden’s son, Hunter, and one of his brothers, James.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump’s Army of Angry White Men
description: This group will continue to fight for Trump and he knows that.
content: This election will test the country’s core.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Trump Had One Last Story to Sell. The Wall Street Journal Wouldn’t Buy It.
description: Inside the White House’s secret, last-ditch effort to change the narrative, and the election — and the return of the media gatekeepers.
content: By early October, even people inside the White House believed President Trump’s re-election campaign needed a desperate rescue mission. So three men allied with the president gathered at a house in McLean, Va., to launch one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Francis Appoints First African-American Cardinal
description: Wilton Gregory, the archbishop of Washington, was among 13 new cardinals named on Sunday.
content: WASHINGTON — Pope Francis on Sunday named Wilton Gregory, the archbishop of Washington, a cardinal, elevating the first African-American to the Catholic church’s highest governing body, a groundbreaking act in a year when demands for racial justice have consumed the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Titans’ Missed Kick Keeps Steelers Unbeaten
description: Pittsburgh (6-0) was brilliant for one half, then needed a defensive stand and a missed field-goal attempt to hold off Tennessee (5-1) in a battle of two of the A.F.C.’s most formidable teams.
content: After the ball hooked right of the upright, the Pittsburgh Steelers jumped and danced and cavorted along their sideline. As it fluttered wide, quarterback Ben Roethlisberger’s jaw fell. He appeared to mutter, “He missed it,” to no one in particular, before turning, smiling, to his teammates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jack Nicas
title: Apple, Google and a Deal That Controls the Internet
description: In a landmark antitrust complaint, the Justice Department is targeting a secretive partnership that is worth billions of dollars to both companies.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai, the chief executives of Apple and Google, were photographed eating dinner together in 2017 at an upscale Vietnamese restaurant called Tamarine, the picture set off a tabloid-worthy frenzy about the relationship between the two most powerful companies in Silicon Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Brett Phillips Becomes the Rays’ Latest Unlikely Hero
description: Phillips may have been the last hitter the Rays wanted in a do-or-die situation in the World Series. But he delivered one of the most memorable hits in team history to win Game 4.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — Before Kenley Jansen threw the final pitch of a World Series game for the ages, Dan Johnson threw the first — virtually, anyway. Johnson tossed it on a snow-covered youth diamond in Minnesota, and the video beamed from the scoreboard high atop Globe Life Field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: The Essential Agatha Christie
description: Whether you want to be scared, shocked or stumped, we will help you pick your poison. Strychnine-laced cocoa, anyone?
content: When I was 11, my beloved sixth-grade teacher, Sara McBee — who still sported a 1960s bouffant and frosted lipstick — read aloud to the class every day after lunch. At first, I wasn’t sure about being read to. It seemed childish, a throwback to first and second grades. But Mrs. McBee was a terrific reader, voicing all the characters with verve, and she picked novels I’d never heard of in small-town Texas: Chaim Potok’s “The Chosen,” Harper Lee’s “To Kill a Mockingbird.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 26, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder and Geneva Abdul
title: With Vacation Rentals Empty, European Cities See a Chance to Reclaim Housing
description: Platforms like Airbnb have been criticized for raising living costs in popular cities. Now, officials are trying to move properties aimed at tourists to long-term leases.
content: LISBON — Long before the coronavirus swept across Europe this spring, many cities had been complaining that a proliferation of short-term apartment rentals aimed at tourists through platforms like Airbnb was driving up housing costs for locals and destroying the character of historic districts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Why False Positives Merit Concern, Too
description: False negatives are not the only troublesome outcome of a faulty coronavirus test.
content: In the high-stakes world of coronavirus testing, one mistake has taken center stage: the dreaded false negative, wherein a test mistakenly deems an infected person to be virus-free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Katherine Cusumano
title: Hail the Supermoon and Howl at a Canine Costume Contest
description: (Or vice versa.) It’s Halloween week and treats abound, from oysters to ballet to a Sam Smith concert.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: The Sunday Read: ‘My Mustache, My Self’
description: How one writer’s facial hair experiment in quarantine led to a deep consideration of his Blackness.
content: During months of pandemic isolation, Wesley Morris, a critic at large for The New York Times, decided to grow a mustache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Sashimi With Spaghetti? Yes, Please. And a Slice of Mango on Top.
description: Welcome to the wonderful, threatened world of Brazil’s “quilo” restaurants.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The Swedes gave the world the concept of “smorgasbord,” a celebratory buffet meal featuring a variety of hot and cold dishes. But it was the Brazilians who elevated this gastronomic mishmash to a new level. By adding a singular touch of inventiveness, recurrence and chaos, they gave the world something special: the “quilo” restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Niu, Kassie Bracken and Alexandra Eaton
title: Russia Created an Election Disinformation Playbook. Here’s How Americans Evolved It.
description: In 2016, Russia developed a simple but effective playbook to undermine U.S. elections with disinformation on social media. Four years later, Americans are using the same playbook on each other.
content: A deluge of misinformation is hitting the U.S. elections, and this time election experts are more worried about it coming from Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Conservative News Sites Fuel Voter Fraud Misinformation
description: Breitbart, The Washington Examiner and others amplify false claims of rampant cheating in what a new Harvard study calls a “propaganda feedback loop.”
content: In the final stretch of the 2020 campaign, right-leaning news sites with millions of readers have published dozens of false or misleading headlines and articles that effectively back unsubstantiated claims by President Trump and his allies that mail-in ballots threaten the integrity of the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Ella Koeze, Rachel Shorey and Lazaro Gamio
title: The Two Americas Financing the Trump and Biden Campaigns
description: For the first time, data reveals not only when Joe Biden overtook President Trump in the money race, but also what parts of the country powered his surge.
content: For the first time, data reveals not only when Joe Biden overtook President Trump in the money race, but also what parts of the country powered his surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Niu, Kassie Bracken, Alexandra Eaton, Will Lloyd, Yousur Al-Hlou and Aaron Byrd
title: How Homegrown Disinformation Could Disrupt This U.S. Election
description: In 2016, Russia developed a simple, effective playbook to undermine U.S. elections with disinformation on social media. Four years later, Americans are using the same playbook on each other.
content: In 2016, Russia developed a simple, effective playbook to undermine U.S. elections with disinformation on social media. Four years later, Americans are using the same playbook on each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: 4 Current Affairs Podcasts for Curious Children
description: Daily, biweekly and weekly shows deliver kids the news at their level, and help contextualize the world around them.
content: What do children make of the day’s headlines? The endless deluge of news is staggering and tough to get a handle on, even for grown-ups. And with disinformation packaged as journalism rampant on social media, there is an urgent need to help kids tell the difference between truth and propaganda. These news podcasts are perfect for young people seeking a better understanding of what the adults are fussing about and for parents who want to help their children learn how to engage critically with the world around them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Using Humor as a Political Weapon Against Trump
description: Readers react to a column by Nicholas Kristof urging the use of mockery. Also: When writers feel constrained; immigration reform.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: The TV Window to Other Worlds
description: Readers respond to an Op-Ed essay on learning through watching.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
